ocr_result: Mandela To Abolish Death Penalty Mandela To Abolish Death Penalty

South Africa's unity government approved draft legislation abolishing the death penalty yesterday, despite di visions within the cabinet, a govern- ment spokesman said. South Africa's unity government approved draft legislation abolishing the death penalty yesterday, despite di visions within the cabinet, a govern- ment spokesman said.

The draft legislation still has to be sent to parliament for approval next year, spokesman Jakes Gerwel said. President Nelson Mandela's ruling African National Congress (ANC) is officially in favour of ending hangings, while its cabinet partners, the National Party and the Inkatha Freedom Party, are in favour of continued executions. Gerwel said the cabinet had agreed The draft legislation still has to be sent to parliament for approval next year, spokesman Jakes Gerwel said. President Nelson Mandela's ruling African National Congress (ANC) is officially in favour of ending hangings, while its cabinet partners, the National Party and the Inkatha Freedom Party, are in favour of continued executions. Gerwel said the cabinet had agreed

that the issue would not divide the unity government and that "parties have the right to their own positions". that the issue would not divide the unity government and that "parties have the right to their own positions".

The draft bill is expected to be debated when parliamentresumes early- next year and the issue is also expected to be heard in the Constitutional Court, which will have to decide whether capital punishment violates the right-to- life clause in the new constitution. The draft bill is expected to be debated when parliamentresumes early- next year and the issue is also expected to be heard in the Constitutional Court, which will have to decide whether capital punishment violates the right-to- life clause in the new constitution.

There have been no hangings in South Africa since 1989, although there are several hundred prisoners on death row: as death sentences are still imposed by the courts. - --- Soyinka To Stand For Him - --- Soyinka To Stand For Him

Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka will accept a special prize in Stockholm tomorrow on behalf of his compatriot Ken Saro-Wiwa, who has been jailed since May. Soyinka broke off a visit to the United States to receive the prize, which will be awarded at a ceremony Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka will accept a special prize in Stockholm tomorrow on behalf of his compatriot Ken Saro-Wiwa, who has been jailed since May. Soyinka broke off a visit to the United States to receive the prize, which will be awarded at a ceremony
in the Swedish parliament tomorrow. in the Swedish parliament tomorrow.

South Africa Names Envoy For Nigeria South Africa Names Envoy For Nigeria

South Africa first ambassador to Nigeria has been appointed. He is Mr. George Sipho Nene. Mr. Nene is among 16 newly appointed ambassadors an- nounced by South African President, Nelson Mandela this morning. Mr Nene South Africa first ambassador to Nigeria has been appointed. He is Mr. George Sipho Nene. Mr. Nene is among 16 newly appointed ambassadors an- nounced by South African President, Nelson Mandela this morning. Mr Nene

has been in Nigeria for some time as ANC representative. Of the 16, one is a lady, Barbara Maskela a sister to the Jazz musician.
